wikipedia_page.main: William Hayes (1871–1940) was a Victorian photographer in YorkHe moved to the small village of Hutton-le-Hole in the North York Moors in 1911, and his studio is now erected there in the Ryedale Folk Museum. (The museum is an open-air museum with other re-erected North Yorkshire buildings.)[1]  The Hayes photographs include some of the family in the studio, which was built of corrugated aluminium with large glass windows.  Many other photographs are of farm workers around Hutton-le-Hole.

response: York was a centre of early photography, as described by Hugh Murray in his 1986 book Photographs and Photographers of York: The Early Years, 1844–79. Photographers who had studios in York included William Hayes, William Pumphrey, and Augustus Mahalski who operated on Davygate and Low Petergate in the 19th century, having come to England as a refugee after serving as a Polish lancer in the Austro-Hungarian war.
